title: RL33748
content: Nuclear weapons will continue to be crucial for U.S. security policy, but maintaining current Cold War-era weapons is becoming challenging. Congress is considering three options: extending the service lives of current warheads, developing a new generation without testing, or resuming nuclear testing. This report focuses on the first two options. The report compares options for maintaining U.S. nuclear weapons: extending current warheads' service lives or developing a new generation without testing. Resuming nuclear testing is also discussed but not considered a separate option. The report discusses options for maintaining U.S. nuclear weapons, including extending current warheads' service lives and developing a new generation without testing. The Stockpile Stewardship Program (SSP) was established in 1993 to ensure the preservation of U.S. nuclear weapons capabilities without testing. NNSA requests $6,511.3 million for SSP in FY2008. The Reliable Replacement Warhead Program (LEP) aims to maintain warheads by replacing components with newly-fabricated ones while maintaining high confidence in current warheads for the long term. The Reliable Replacement Warhead (RRW) program was initiated by Congress to improve the reliability, longevity, and certifiability of existing weapons and their components. NNSA executes the RRW program in cooperation with DOD. The Nuclear Weapons Council, in cooperation with DOD, oversees and coordinates nuclear weapon activities. A warhead Project Officers Group develops military characteristics for new warheads or modifications. Safety is the top priority, followed by security/use control. Other priorities include certifiability, cost, longevity, manufacturability, reliability, survivability, and yield. NNSA must also meet policy goals in designing or maintaining warheads. NNSA must meet policy goals in designing or maintaining warheads, including reducing the need for nuclear testing, improving safety and use control, designing for manufacturing and maintenance, fulfilling current mission requirements, upgrading the nuclear weapons complex, and reducing costs. A competition between New Mexico and California design teams was initiated by the Nuclear Weapons Council to create preliminary warhead designs. The Nuclear Weapons Council selected the California design for the Reliable Replacement Warhead (RRW) program in March 2007. This warhead, now called "WR1," aims to sustain U.S. nuclear weapons without testing. The development of nuclear weapons follows defined phases, with NNSA requesting funds for design definition and cost study in FY2008.
